p.s: In the following text I am going to analyze the character of Helen and how she is being described by Pearl.
Helen is an eight yearsyear old girl that looks about five because of her little height (cf. ll. 1-2).
She smells like roasted marshmellowsmarhsmallows (cf. l. 3) and is a very talkative person, who smiles a lot (cf. ll. 3-5).

Pearl describes her as the true-blue foster child (l. 11) because of the amount of different kinds of foster homes she has been living in and the fact that she doesn't know her real parents or where she came from (cf. ll. 5-6).

The changes in her life mix up her depiction of her own past as she tells Pearl that she has a white and a black mommy (l. 6), ten brothers and eleven sisters (l. 7) and is from both Ethiopia and Finland (l. 8).

She also says that she has two twin brothers and two twin sisters (l. 9), what is physically impossible and underlines the fact that she is confused about her past or that she maybe just gives the words a metaphoric meaning.
After that she tells Pearl about the rough times she had to go through at her different homes.
For example that she was only given cereals to eat (l. 14) or the times she had to sleep on the floor (cf. l. 16).

AllthoughAlthough she nearly tells only negative things about her past she mentions some friends she had at some of her old homes, which she wants to stay in contact with, through the cellphones she keeps in a plastic bag, each being connected with one of her past foster homes (cf. ll. 25-27).

Nobody teached Helen how to do simple things (cf. ll. 11-13) or how to behave in front of other people, what makes her a very honest person e.g. when she tells Pearl that she smells like bug-off (l. 42).
AllthoughAlthough her liflife was hard and difficuiltdifficult Helen seems like a very hopefullhopeful person.
She has dreams about a white Christmas in Florida (cf. ll. 18-19), smiles and talks a lot (cf. ll. 3-5) and likes to be kissed on the forehead (cf. l. 19).
She stays hopefullhopeful, allthoughalthough nobody worries about her drinking enough water (cf. 19) and her speaking to herself in the third person (cf. l. 17), what makes her a strong character.
Taking everything into acountaccount you can see that Helen is a strong and hopefullhopeful girl, but her difficuiltdifficult past seems to affect her personality a lot.
It almost seems like each of the different foster homes she has been to represents a part of her mixed personality what confuses her and leads to her acting abnormal sometimes.
She needs love in her life to find a way to become really happy and to live a good life.
